data.title: Multicoloured Carlisle Cathedral.
data.meta_description:
The dominant building material in the Carlisle region is the Agra Red/Pink Sandstone and much of the cathedral appears to have been built with just that. Other local stone has also been used and when you add some black discolouration to the mix created in the Industrial Age the cathedral takes on a multicoloured look. 
	
	Of course being a border city the English and Scots have fought over the location for centuries. During the English Civil War, a portion of the nave of the cathedral was demolished by the Scottish Presbyterian Army in order to use the stone to reinforce Carlisle Castle. As a result the shape and appearance of the cathedral has changed a great deal since 1122 when building work first commenced.
data.text:
The dominant building material in the Carlisle region is the Agra Red/Pink Sandstone and much of the cathedral appears to have been built with just that. Other local stone has also been used and when you add some black discolouration to the mix created in the Industrial Age the cathedral takes on a multicoloured look.

Of course being a border city the English and Scots have fought over the location for centuries. During the English Civil War, a portion of the nave of the cathedral was demolished by the Scottish Presbyterian Army in order to use the stone to reinforce Carlisle Castle. As a result the shape and appearance of the cathedral has changed a great deal since 1122 when building work first commenced.
